title: Options.locals no passed into templates
body:
As far as I can tell, this was introduced in 4780168ba8c0095679f0. Templates used to be invoked with options.locals as the context object; now they're being passed just options, which means within the template you need to say locals.foo instead of just foo -- which breaks templates for the behaviour in the 1.x series. 

I'm not sure if the fix is to return to passing options.locals, or to merge options.locals into options; I'm not too clear on what the motivations may be for the changes in how options is being handled.

title: Add view lookup paths
body:
basically `require.paths` but for views :) this is not very clean as a setting, something like this would be better:

```
app.viewPaths.push('whatever')
```

still ugly, or `app.set('views', [one,two,three])` which is ok but non-progressive

title: support for node 0.4 https.createServer
body:
In node 0.4, it's no longer possible to call setSecure() to bless a server as SSL. One must create an instance of https.Server. At present, that's a couple layers below express.createServer.  Are there plans to support the new SSL mechanism in a future release?
Is there a work around for now?

title: Fix for query parameters being lost if routed in a certain way
body:
Hi TJ,

I've put in a quick, possibly horrible fix for a bug I noticed when using modules. The query parameters were being lost because of the way the server was handling requests.
Basically further up somewhere the req.url was losing the query string, and this.use in Server was always clearing the query of the request then rebuilding if the url had a query string.

Setup to see this bug was:
- Basic server with it's own set of routes.
- app.use('./apath', require('anotherServer'));
- A route in anotherServer spitting out query string
- Request the route in anotherServer and watch query string dissapear.

Let me know if you need more information / you have any suggestions, it's blocking my project from working as expected.

Thanks,
Danny.

title: package.json lists dependancy on connect >= 0.5.x
body: The '0.5.x' dependancy is interpreted by npm as later than 0.5.d for any numeric 'd', which means Express currently can't be installed via npm, as the connect dependancy cannot be satisfied (at least, not with any released version; an 'npm link'd connect would work).

title: Add eco (Embedded CoffeeScript) to template languages section in Guide
body:
Hi,

Sam Stephenson's eco (Embedded CoffeeScript, http://github.com/sstephenson/eco) looks like a great addition to the list of template languages. I added it the MarkDown and HTML versions of the guide; I think it's worth considering.

Best,
Milan

title: Async view support
body:
This is a somewhat controversial topic for views. Here are my opinions.

The good:
- we could pass "promise"-like objects to the view and forget about them (db queries etc)
- async helpers
- early head flush

The bad:
- complicates, and in turn slows down the view system
- graceful error reporting becomes much more difficult
- promotes the use of a view for non-view-like computation

title: local values persisting across separate calls to partial
body:
let's say you have a partial.jade that simply outputs the value of _foo_: ``` p= foo ``` and and index.jade that calls/includes it: ``` !=partial('partial_persistent_locals/partial', {locals: {foo: "bar1"}}) !=partial('partial_persistent_locals/partial', {locals: {}}) ``` the output is: ```

bar1

bar1

``` the value of _foo_ should not persist between the 2 calls. this prevents the ability to implement default values for the parameters to a partial.

title: annoying: The 'sys' module is now called 'util'. It should have a similar interface.
body:
Since node 0.3.0, sys module has been changed to util. It works (for now), although it is supposedly deprecated, but the error is annoying, gets in logfiles, etc.... and is called in only one place throughout express.

Line 15 of response.js should change from
  , pump = require('sys').pump

to
  , pump = require('util').pump

Thanks.

title: Small patch to install.sh to make it work under FreeBSD
body: FreeBSD's tar (and possibly other BSDs) need an explicit "-f -" to read from STDIN. Without it, tar tries reading from a tape drive.

title: Express doesn't get its environment set when invoked using spark -E <environment>
body:
I'm the guy who's been pestering you and creationix about pushing the spark version with NODE_ENV support to the npm repo for a while. That's been done now, but it seems like the transition to NODE_ENV hasn't been completed. Given an app.js like this: 
var app = module.exports = require('express').createServer();
app.configure('production', function () {console.log("Express: production");});
app.configure('development', function () {console.log("Express: development");});
$ spark -E production
Express: development
Spark server(2991) listening on http://*:3000 in production mode
However setting NODE_ENV works: 
$ NODE_ENV=production spark
Express: production
Spark server(2992) listening on http://*:3000 in production mode
I see two possible fixes, either Express should check (process.sparkEnv && process.sparkEnv.name) before falling back to development in server.js, or spark should set process.env.NODE_ENV when it encounters the -E switch or any of its aliases. Probably the latter :) Best regards, Papandreou

error:14090086:SSL routines:SSL3_GET_SERVER_CERTIFICATE:certificate verify faile
d
More details here: http://curl.haxx.se/docs/sslcerts.html

curl performs SSL certificate verification by default, using a "bundle"
 of Certificate Authority (CA) public keys (CA certs). If the default
 bundle file isn't adequate, you can specify an alternate file
 using the --cacert option.
If this HTTPS server uses a certificate signed by a CA represented in
 the bundle, the certificate verification probably failed due to a
 problem with the certificate (it might be expired, or the name might
 not match the domain name in the URL).
If you'd like to turn off curl's verification of the certificate, use
 the -k (or --insecure) option.

The examples work fine which use:
var express = require('../express/lib/express');

but I was thinking I should be able to use the lib that has been installed via npm for my own app. (npm was installed via brew) 

i.e. 
var express = require('express');

When I mod the example mvc like this and start the server it all loads up fine. Index page loads and the .json route loads but the users or /users/1 etc all fail with a 500. 

I'm guessing that I'm missing something super simple.. any help would be much appreciated.

Thanks and congrats on building what looks to be a killer framework.

title: move render code to its own project
body: Express has done a lot of cool stuff for rendering templates that could be used in other projects or by other web frameworks that don't want to have to implement this themselves. It would be cool to move all the render code (finding which template to render and finding the right module for doing so) into it's own project to share the love.

title: partials in current directory
body:
it would be nice to be able to have a partial directory per directory, rather than one single partial directory in the root. (or dare I say it, the rails style of "_partial").
Once a site gets beyond a certain size, one single directory for all partials is very unwieldy. Is this possible ?

title: staticProvider over SSL serves half the file
Async View Support
body:
This is a somewhat controversial topic for views. Here are my opinions.

The good:
- we could pass "promise"-like objects to the view and forget about them (db queries etc)
- async helpers

The bad:
- complicates, and in turn slows down the view system
- error reporting becomes nearly impossible (if we write to the socket before a query is finished for example)

there would extremely minimal performance gains from async views, perhaps in some cases even a decrease. if we wish to perform error handling in a reasonable way we cannot write to the socket before all promises are complete, meaning the view system basically becomes control flow. This is why I am personally against the idea, however I do like the idea of supporting async helpers which could simply `next(err)` on exception

title: Rendering stops for a jade template when it contains an empty js file
body:
When attaching a blank javascript in the body, express doesn't render anything below the script and the connection stays open.

The jade template: http://gist.github.com/640269

title: I am using ejs, can i have many yields in a layout?
body:
In rails, in application.html.erb,

<%= yield :header %>
<%= yield %>
<%= yield :footer %>

In our awsome expressjs,

<%- body %>

can i have many yields in a layout?  

Thanks
o(∩_∩)o...

title: settings locals variables on a partial no longer works
body:
I just updated from tag 1.0.0rc4 and my partials no longer work properly. Example partial:

!= partial('restaurants/_restaurant_js.html.ejs', {locals: {restaurant: restaurant.data}})

In the partial, I can't access any properties of the 'restaurant' variable. But it worked fine before the upgrade. It looks like locals are no longer being set properly

~/local/realie/vendor/express$ git submodule update

Clone of 'git://github.com/visionmedia/class.js.git' into submodule path 'lib/support/class' failed

title: return render in app.register

express, sessions, authentication and socket.io?
Socket-IO and Express/Connect
body:
hi,

I've been trying to get Socket-IO to work with Express/Connect all day. Has anyone go this working?

I'm of course using the http://github.com/bnoguchi/Socket.IO-connect lib, which requires this patched version of Connect: http://github.com/bnoguchi/Connect/tree/serverAccessFromHandle. There must be an easier way. I'd like to benefit from both libs.

Thanks in advance for anyone who's got a handle on this.

title: styles.css in helloworld invalid
body:
Minor issue but in the helloworld example the layout.jade file references styles.css when it should reference styles.less

`Line 5: link(rel='stylesheet', href='/stylesheets/style.css')`

Should be (I believe)

`Line 5: link(rel='stylesheet', href='/stylesheets/style.less')`
